content: huh a letter from frankie
all right let's see what we got here dear mr
wylock mr please you can refer to me as your god king
you may not know who i am yeah i do we met in north carolina last year
although at the time i didn't realize who you were
but i have a bone to pick with you oh maybe that's because i didn't realize
who you were i wanted to challenge you to a duel to the death
but my girlfriend informed me that that's not a thing people do anymore
yeah girlfriend sure so after my girlfriend shut down three more of my
ideas she suggested i simply challenge you to a non-deadly craft off
using non-radioactive materials i suggest that we have your patrons
choose the theme and my patrons choose the material okay
mine chose diesel punk skytrain and yours chose salvaged electronics
yours truly frankie d crafter yours truly your god king
here we go
what exactly is diesel punk yeah i definitely could not have a
repeat of the steampunk tile incident here so let's go ahead and
search okay diesel punk is a genre similar to steampunk that combines the
aesthetics of the diesel based technology of the interwar period
through the 1950s with retro-futuristic technology
and post-modern sensibilities okay a bit of a mouthful
but i think from this image over on the right i sort of am starting to get it
i'm just gonna go ahead and search for diesel punk train
ah okay so that 1930s 40s 50s sort of art deco look
oh i like this one yeah i like this so this will be challenging it's very clean
looking i'm not going to be able to hide my sins with weathering
i'm going to use this as the basis so let's get started
and remember that our sponsor is heroes hoard for you 3d printers out there
excellent selection including all true tiles lines
what i've got here is a dvd player from the attic it's been up there for
eight uh maybe 10 years something like that
anyway there's surprisingly little inside of it just took it apart
use the screwdriver pry bar whatever is needed
and found all kinds of neat little components some of these i'm going to
use decoratively and i decided that some i will actually use
as electronic components i'll explain what i mean later
circuit boards not very diesel punk but all this other stuff i'm gonna find a
use for whether it's in this project or another
it is helpful when taking apart old electronics to have
flush cut snips and a soldering iron handy
another preliminary i know i'm gonna need christmas lights i've used these
before in several projects so i won't go too deep into this but
these are the led kind so i'm gonna go ahead and test them
into my electronic supply box to get some wire and some resistors
now some basic research on these led christmas lights
it varies from manufacturer to manufacturer but in general
they have a forward voltage of about 1.2 and an ideal carrying current between 40
and 60 milliamps so on this 9 volt battery i tried out a
100 ohm resistor and it worked just fine
okay pringles can i cut off the top and the bottom
and then i cut it in half exactly and then i cut
those halves in half a ruler is essential here
so these will kind of form the top of the train that tubular
shape that you see this is the basis for it this is how we start
now the curve at the front is going to be a little tricky
what i did is measure out one inch increments
five of them and then cut almost all the way through just maybe a few millimeters
left uncut and then the idea is that those
will fold under each other a little bit to form the curve a little
dab of hot glue at each i guess fold or cascade whatever
you'd call it and i end up with the curve very nice
and you can see that smooth silver on the inside you may think that nothing's
going to stick to that it's actually very papery it does take
glue very well the hot glue sticks just fine
doing the other side and this is mirrored so be careful of that
now with some cereal box just a thinner cardstock it's my other
preferred material i cut a one and a quarter inch strip and hot glued it to
the underside just welding it basically with hot glue from
the underside i also threw some patches on there you
can see to reinforce those joints now moving on to chipboard this is
graphics medium chipboard it's the stuff at the back of a legal pad
but you can buy it in bulk like i do if you want there's links in the video
description below anyway i cut a shape to form the wall of
the train car and it's going to need two pieces but
again this is just hot glued on to the inside
and then hot gluing a panel onto the back and for these weird curved pieces
i find that rather than measure it's easier to just hot glue on an oversized
piece and then cut away the excess using the
body of the piece as a jig like you see me doing with the
scissors here that's how you get the smoothest result
so here's the shell nice and strong ready to go
this is double corrugated cardboard i harvest this stuff from
the things that i buy anyway i'm gonna trace the shell
onto it and then cut it out this is the base plate for the actual playable
interior for doing curves multiple passes like six or seven passes starting
with a very light one we'll get you a good curve in double
corrugated cardboard then i have some very light card stock
even paper would work here whatever this is corrugation cladding so
i just hot glue it onto the edge very nice you might recognize these wood
bits from the crafting store like michael's or a hobby lobby or
whatever you have in your neck of the woods
so i'm going to glue three of these to some chipboard cut away the excess
and this is a bank of hover pads or engines or whatever you want to call
them there will be 12 total three per bank i
black bombed them punched holes to mount christmas lights here
here's where those leds come in the blue ones testing it with a nine volt
and it glows nicely this is gonna look good all right next up base coat with a
metallic silver inside and out doing it on the inside as
well really helps the glow to be more pronounced
and you can see these are mounted to the back using hot glue
from here i'm soldering on the resistors one for each led
and all the electronics in this piece are going to be done in parallel
a lot of battery draw but it is a 9 volt so i'm not too worried
also what i'm doing here is strain relief putting some hot glue on to
mitigate any minor bending that might happen and to prevent the leads from
touching each other hardy ready to go now i'm going to cut
the pads to which those engines will be mounted
and i'm cutting at a 45 degree angle here so look at my hand
and i'll show it again there turn cutting at 45 degrees
so that i get a nice rectangle with these sloped edges
just like that and then when these are hot glued on
they'll be at a nice angle you won't actually be able to see the led
itself just the glow emanating out and sort of downward
and these two assemblies get glued to the underside of the base plate
at positions that are just aesthetically pleasing so you can see the line on
there i pre-measured where i wanted it to go
and then i eyeballed to make sure there was some overhang on each side
there's about five millimeters on each side and that's important that's what
the shell actually sits on to make everything
flush all right so at this point i got to do
some fun stuff the electronics start coming together
tying all these leads together checking the polarities first
using solder this is some good old-fashioned leaded solder
that is literally from the basement of a campus
nuclear reactor that i was a licensed operator for
i smuggled it out on my last day after graduation anyway again for strain
relief hot gluing these down once they're all tied together
now i'm checking for roughly where i want the rooms to be i know i want there
to be a pilot area a middle main gathering area and then an
engine room so for the engine room that's where the
9 volt battery is going to go it's sort of going to be the power source just
like the engine would be and so i'm just sort of figuring out
where the wall is going to go and then punching a hole through to run
the mains for the 9 volt this is a header from the dvd player and
these wires are very thin wispy um very delicate i think they'd be
easy to run through corrugation and stuff so i'm going to switch to using
these instead of that stiffer stranded lead wire that i was
using measuring out and puncturing holes in
just the right places in what will become the wall so only going
halfway through like one layer of this double corrugated
and that way i could run a pair of wires through the channel and they're hidden
in the wall i punched a corresponding hole in the
floor on the base plate pulled the wires through and then hot
glued that wall in place
the compartment for the nine volt battery was simply made out of
rectangles of chipboard i just measured out how big i needed add a few
millimeters in each direction and hot glue them on there piece of cake
for the top of it for the lid i cut two
rectangles one a bit smaller than the other
and these are actually measured down to the millimeter very precise
because you'll see it's sort of keyed to fit in
to the opening this way the lid can't slide around
there very sturdy you see what i mean and then this thing it looks like a
transformer maybe i it came out of the dvd player but i
think i'm going to mount it on the top it kind of looks like
uh i i don't know maybe engine ish and then these capacitors also cut off the
circuit boards from the dvd player these will look like cylinders
and then another wall with wires inside to create the
compartment for the pilot or the driver whatever you want to call it
and while i was up there i was thinking about control panel so here's just a
little bit of chipboard and here's some resistors ripped off the
dvd player if i cut off one end of the leads and
sort of unbend the other one they're nice looking levers sort of
either i don't know diesel punk steampunk certainly not modern
definitely anachronistic
once again rocking the shell of a hair curler from the dollar store
snipped a short length of that and then glued on some chipboard
punched a hole and mounted a single throw switch
in there this will tap back to the battery mains
and so basically up in the compartment where you would control
the train that's where you'll control all of the power like for the lights and
stuff so you can see i've put a hole in the
floor there and i'm doing a little painting ahead of time as well because
it's cleaner that way but ultimately the whole control panel
would be run through and that switch is gonna turn stuff on
and off for all the lights in the piece
i don't have any drawing like artistic talent so i google image searched for
some art deco wallpaper printed it up cut it punched holes in
the corresponding areas and then glued it onto the wall
with a glue stick those leads i attached some amber
colored christmas lights to and for these i think i used the 220 ohm
resistor because most leds other than blue
have a lower forward voltage but honestly it would probably work fine
with 100 as well anyways those just got glued to the wall
the slack taken up everything tied together underneath and
here's the first test run legit the first time i turned everything
on and it's good to go 12 engines and four cozy dim amber
lights now i'm not yet done with the shell
let's take another look at the inspirational image i'm going off of
there's these personnel walkways sort of on these uh
buttresses or flanks on the side of the shell
so to build that going back to chipboard and i'm going to cut it at a
slant to sort of contrast with the curve that's at the front
i think that sort of is one of the elements of the
the diesel punk art deco whatever of this period
and then a three-quarter inch wide strip of double corrugated cardboard to make
the walkway so that gets hot glued on and while i
was here it occurred to me those curves up in the front for those
seams i'm gonna lay down thin beads of hot glue to make them look
like weld lines i did this before for the fuel depot and
it worked out great then so we'll see how this goes
also while i was at it some cereal box card stock to just cover up
a bunch of the other exposed edges and generally just clean it up make it look
a little nicer so with two supports on the side and
then some healthy beads of hot glue i put on the chipboard slab and you can
see i had pre-drawn and cut out the like oval shaped
nacelles where the engines are going to show
through yeah just like that so there's a quarter inch there that is
going to allow the miniature to sort of lean against the body of the train even
though most bases are one inch wide so that makes it a perfectly playable
exterior surface like if you're being boarded or something
i've got some smooth gloss slick paper here so i'm going to take this outside
and prime it before trying to paint it while the primer is drying here are some
wooden crafting picks i just painted them up with a metallic
silver and then white glued on a few flat back
gemstones 12 of them six per stick these are going to be like the indicator
lights for which engines are operational and i glued them to the wall behind the
pilot because it can't be a ylc project
without gratuitous bejeweling this is some thick low gauge wire i
don't remember where i got it i tried to bend it into shape to sort of
trail along the side of the train again like the
source image but proved too difficult to work with so instead these styrene
crafting rods they're already straight out of the box
and they're pretty flexible you can use heat to keep them in place but i was
able to do it just with glue so i used some dabs of super glue in the
right spots a little bit of accelerant and so that's how i achieve those
runners at the back of the train i want a
platform to stand on so i measured out some double corrugated cardboard and cut
a piece and then i clad it with cereal box now
this is i don't know half inch thick so it's got
a lip and it sort of overhangs a little bit on the top
then hot glued to the back done and done at this point i also realized it'd be
good to have access ladders to go from that platform
up to the catwalks on the side of the shell so
again back to the dollar store hair curlers taking the interior portion out
and cutting one row of rungs out perfect okay so i lied earlier
now i'm going to take it out and do some primer except there's one other thing i

off this needs to mirror the back so that's what i did
i cut another curved piece of double corrugated to attach to the front

and then glued that to the underside of the base plate
what this does is hide the bottom of the front of the shell and sort of give it a

inspirational image now for real once it's primed up i gave

metallic silver and went all over i used some masking tape
put on some stripes did some details really just two colors so far
the metallic silver and the dark bluish gray going for a clean look
so no weathering for the catwalks this is cross stitch mesh
sometimes referred to as granny grating again there's links in the video

and then use some white glue to set that into the catwalk
moving back to the inside for the actual gathering meeting area
i cut various lengths of popsicle stick and hot glued them on

base coated with black and to make sure i got into the edges a

sort of an orangey color i think i did actually mix in some pure

and lastly a honey brown so this is the typical wood kit that i've used for
all wood that i've ever done again it's lightly applied against the grain
and in the end you get a real nice looking sort of

this is the actual platter that the dvd would sit on

you can score and then gouge out with a pen to
